17 varsity teams |colors =[[Blue]] and [[Gold (color)|Gold]] {{color box|#002d62}} {{color box|#c5960c}} |mascot =Roary the Panther |nickname =[[FIU Golden Panthers|Golden Panthers]] |affiliations =[[AACSB]], [[Oak Ridge Associated Universities|ORAU]], [[Phi Beta Kappa Society|Î¦ÎÎS]], [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools|SACS]], [[State University System of Florida|SUS]] |website =[http://www.fiu.edu/ www.fiu.edu] |logo =[[File:FIULogo Vertical.png|175px]] }} '''Florida International University''' (commonly referred to as '''FIU''') is an [[United States|American]] [[public university|public]] [[research university]] in [[Miami-Dade County|metropolitan]] [[Miami]], [[Florida]], in the [[United States]], with its main campus in [[University Park, Florida|University Park]]."[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US1273287&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on University Park CDP, Florida]." [[U.S. Census Bureau]]. Retrieved on September 28, 2009."[http://campusmaps.fiu.edu/ FIU Campus Maps]." Floria International University. Retrieved on April 27, 2011. Florida International University is classified as a top-tier Research University with high research activity by the [[The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|Carnegie Foundation]],http://rosenberg.fiu.edu/ and is a first-tier research university as designated by the [[Florida Legislature]].{{cite web| url=http://carnegiefoundation.org/classifications/sub.asp?key=748&subkey=13831&start=782 |title=Carnegie Classification |accessdate=2008-08-27}} Founded in 1965, FIU is the youngest university to be awarded a [[Phi Beta Kappa]] chapter by the [[Phi Beta Kappa Society]], the country's oldest academic [[honor society]].{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/releases/2000/pbk10-23.htm|title=FIU, youngest university awarded PBK chapter|accessdate=2008-01-10|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070903120615/http%3A//news.fiu.edu/releases/2000/pbk10-23.htm |archivedate = September 3, 2007|deadurl=yes}} FIU offers 191 programs of study with more than 280 [[Academic major|majors]] in 26 colleges and schools. FIU offers many graduate programs, including [[Florida International University School of Architecture|architecture]], [[Florida International University College of Business Administration|business administration]], [[Florida International University College of Engineering and Computing|engineering]], [[Florida International University College of Law|law]], and [[FIU Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine|medicine]], offering 82 [[master's degrees]], 29 [[Doctorate|doctoral degrees]], and 3 [[professional degree]]s.{{cite web|url=http://government.fiu.edu/06DidYouKnow.asp|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070612150608/http://government.fiu.edu/06DidYouKnow.asp|archivedate=2007-06-12|title=FIU, Did You Know?|accessdate=2007-06-01}} FIU is one of Florida's primary graduate research universities, and awards close to 3,000 graduate and professional degrees annually.http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Degrees/degrees.pdf FIU is the [[List of largest United States university campuses by enrollment|15th-largest university in the United States]], the 4th-largest university in Florida, and the largest in [[South Florida]].{{cite web|url=http://www.miamitodaynews.com/news/080828/story-profile.shtml|title=Miami Today|accessdate=2008-08-28}} For Fall 2010, total enrollment was 44,010 students, including 11,109 [[graduate student]]s, and 2,974 full-time faculty with over 161,000 [[alumni]] around the world.{{cite web|url=http://opir.fiu.edu/quickfacts.htm|title=Quick Facts about FIU|accessdate=2007-05-19}}{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}{{Dead link|date=August 2011}} In 2007, FIU's research expenditure was $89.1 million, with an endowment of $140 million.http://www.flbog.org/resources/quickfacts/ Since 2007, more [[valedictorian]]s from [[South Florida]] choose to attend FIU than any other university in the country.{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/releases/best_in_class/valedictorians/pdf/Virginia2.indd2.pdf|format=PDF|title=FIU attracts more valedictorians from South Florida than any other university in the country|accessdate=2007-11-22}}http://news.fiu.edu/releases/best_in_class/index.htm For Fall 2009, the average incoming freshmen had an average [[SAT]] score of 1126, a 26 [[ACT (examination)|ACT]] score and a 3.24 high school [[GPA]].{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://wordpress.fiu.edu/magazine/2008/08/26/fiu-30/ |title=FIU Magazine » Features » FIU 3.0 |publisher=Wordpress.fiu.edu |date= |accessdate=2008-10-27}}http://www.clay.k12.fl.us/khh/Guidance%20Folder/Matrix.pdf ==History== ===Founding: 1943 to 1969=== The story of Florida International University's founding began in 1943, when state Senator [[Ernest R. Graham (politician)|Ernest 'Cap' Graham]] (father of future Florida governor and U.S. senator [[Bob Graham]]) presented the state legislature with the initial proposal for the establishment of a public university in South Florida. While his bill did not pass, Graham persisted in presenting his proposal to colleagues, advising them of Miami's need for a state university. He felt the establishment of a public university was necessary to serve the city's growing population.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/brief_history2|title=History from 1943 to 1979|accessdate=2007-11-09}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In 1964, Senate Bill 711 was introduced by Florida Senator Robert M. Haverfield. It instructed the state Board of Education and the [[Board of Regents]] (BOR), to begin planning for the development of a state university in Miami. The bill was signed into law by then-governor [[W. Haydon Burns]] in June 1965, marking FIU's official founding. FIU's founding president [[Chuck Perry|Charles "Chuck" Perry]] was appointed by the Board of Regents in July 1969 after a nationwide search. At 32 years old, the new president was the youngest in the history of the State University System and, at the time, the youngest [[university president]] in the country. Perry recruited three co-founders, Butler Waugh, Donald McDowell and Nick Sileo. [[Alvah Chapman, Jr.]], former ''[[Miami Herald]]'' publisher and [[Knight Ridder]] chairman, used his civic standing and media power to assist the effort. In the 1980s, Chapman became chair of the FIU Foundation Board of Trustees. The founders located the campus on the site of the original [[Kendall-Tamiami Executive Airport|Tamiami Airport]] on the [[Tamiami Trail]] ([[U.S. Route 41]]) between Southwest 107th and 117th Avenues, just east of where the West Dade Expressway (now the [[Homestead Extension of Florida's Turnpike]]) was being planned. The abandoned airportâs air traffic control tower became FIUâs first building. It originally had no telephones, no drinking water, and no furniture. Perry decided that the tower should never be destroyed, and it remains on campus, where it is now known variously as the "Ivory Tower," the "Tower Building," or the "Public Safety Tower," and is the former location of the FIU Police Department. ===Opening of the doors: 1969 to 1975=== [[Image:FIU plaza.JPG|225px|thumb|left|The Graham Center, FIU's student union. Over 3.5 million people walk through the Graham Center every year, making it the heart of student life at FIU.{{cite web|url= http://guc.fiu.edu/index.cfm?Type=About&subType=home&Page=AtaGlance|title=Graham Center information|accessdate=2008-11-14}}]] In September 1972, 5,667 students entered the new state university, the largest opening day enrollment at the time. Previously, Miami had been the largest city in the country lacking a public baccalaureate-granting institution. Eighty percent of the student body had just graduated from Dade County Junior College (now [[Miami-Dade College]]). A typical student entering FIU was 25 years old and attending school full-time while holding down a full-time job. Forty-three percent were married. Negotiations with the [[University of Miami]] and Dade County Junior College led FIU to open as an upper-division only school. It would be 9 years before lower-division classes were added. The first commencement, held in June 1973, took place in the reading room of the ground floor of Primera Casa - the only place large enough on campus for the ceremony. More than 1,500 family members and friends watched FIU's first class of 191 graduates receive their diplomas. By late 1975, after seven years at the helm, [[Chuck Perry|Charles Perry]] felt he had accomplished his goal and left the University to become president and publisher of the Sunday newspaper magazine ''Family Weekly'' (now ''[[USA Weekend]]''), one of the country's largest magazines. When he left, there were more than 10,000 students attending classes and a campus with five major buildings and a sixth being planned. ===Crosby and Wolfe: 1976 to 1986=== [[File:FIU ChemistryPhysics.JPG|thumb|225px|right|FIU is the [[List of largest United States university campuses by enrollment|15th-largest university in the United States]], and the largest in South Florida.{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}]] [[Harold Crosby]], the University's second president and the founding president of the [[University of West Florida]] in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], agreed in 1976 to serve a three-year "interim" term. Under his leadership, FIU's North Miami Campus (which was officially renamed the Bay Vista Campus in 1980, the North Miami Campus in 1987, the North Campus in 1994, and the [[Biscayne Bay Campus]] in 2000) - located on the former Interama site on [[Biscayne Bay]] - was opened in 1977. State Senator Jack Gordon was instrumental in securing funding for the development of the campus. President Crosby emphasized the university's international character, prompting the launching of new programs with an international focus and the recruitment of faculty from the Caribbean and Latin America. President Crosby's resignation in January 1979 triggered the search for a "permanent" president.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/brief_history3.htm|title=History from 1979 to 1986|accessdate=2007-11-09|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070906223202/http%3A//www.fiu.edu/docs/brief_history3.htm |archivedate = September 6, 2007|deadurl=yes}} [[Gregory Baker Wolfe]], a former United States diplomat and then-president of [[Portland State University]] became FIU's third president, from 1979 to 1986. After stepping down as president, Wolfe taught in the university's [[International Relations]] department. The [[student activity center|student union]] on the Biscayne Bay Campus is named in his honor. ===Maidique: 1986 to 2009=== Cuban born [[Modesto A. Maidique]] assumed the presidency at FIU in 1986, becoming the fourth in the university's history. Maidique graduated with a Bachelor of Science, Master of Science, and Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), before joining the private sector. He held academic appointments from MIT, Harvard and Stanford Universities, and has been named to several US Presidential boards and committees."[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US1273287&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on University Park CDP, Florida]." Under his leadership, FIU heralded in an era of unprecedented growth and prestige with all facets of university undergoing major transformations. Physically, the university tripled in size and its enrollment grew to nearly 40,000. During his 23 years as president, the school established the [[Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine]], the [[Florida International University College of Law|FIU College of Law]], the [[Florida International University School of Architecture|FIU School of Architecture]] and the Robert Stempel School of Public Health. Also during his tenure, endowment grew from less than $2 million to over $100 million."[http://president.fiu.edu/about/past]." During Maidiqueâs tenure, the university added 22 new doctoral programs. Research expenditures grew from about $6 million to nearly $110 million as defined by the National Science Foundation."[http://news.fiu.edu/2008/11/fiu-president-modesto-maidique-stepping-down/]." In 2000, FIU attained the highest ranking in the Carnegie Foundation classification system, that of âDoctoral/Research University-Extensive.â"[http://classifications.carnegiefoundation.org/lookup_listings/institution.php]." FIUâs faculty has engaged in research and holds far-reaching expertise in reducing morbidity and mortality from cancer, HIV/AIDS, substance abuse, diabetes and other diseases, and change the approaches to the delivery of health care by medical, public health, nursing and other healthcare professionals, hurricane mitigation, climate change, nano-technologies, forensic sciences, and the development of biomedical devices. The arts also flourished while Maidique was at the helm, with the university acquiring The [[Wolfsonian-FIU|Wolfsonian-FIU Museum]] on Miami Beach and building the Patricia and Phillip [[Frost Art Museum]] on its main campus. In athletics, FIU made inroads in becoming a powerhouse athletic university during Maidique's time as president and he championed the eventual establishment of a NCAA football program. Finally, the school earned membership into Phi Beta Kappa, the nation's oldest honor society."[http://www.pbk.org/infoview/PBK_InfoView.aspx?t=&id=8]." Maidique was the second longest-serving research university president in the nation."[http://news.fiu.edu/2008/11/fiu-president-modesto-maidique-stepping-down/]." Now President Emeritus, he currently serves as the Alvah H. Chapman, Jr., Eminent Scholar Chair in Leadership and Executive Director of the Center for Leadership and Professor of Management at FIU. ===Worlds Ahead: FIU today=== [[File:FIU SOA.JPG|right|thumb|225px|Paul Cejas [[Florida International University School of Architecture|School of Architecture]] Building]] On August 29, 2009, [[Mark B. Rosenberg]] became FIU's fifth president.{{cite web | first = Lissette | last = Lanza | url=http://news.fiu.edu/2009/08/fiu-to-usher-in-new-era-with-installation-of-mark-b-rosenberg-as-its-fifth-president-on-friday/ | title=FIU to Usher in New Era with Installation of Mark B. Rosenberg as its Fifth President on Friday | accessdate=2009-10-09}} FIU's student enrollment of 44,010 (Fall 2010) makes FIU one of the [[List of largest United States university campuses by enrollment|15-largest universities in the United States]].{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/about_fiu.htm|title=About FIU|accessdate=2007-05-19}} [[File:Fiuarboretum.JPG|225px|left|thumb|The Wertheim Conservatory houses many rare species of plants and foliage.]] Having started as a two-year upper division university serving the Miami area, FIU has grown into a traditional university serving students from all over the world. To strengthen this growth, more than $600 million have been invested in construction, with the addition of new residence halls, the on-campus [[FIU Stadium]], recreation center, student center, and Greek Life mansions, as well as the fielding of the Division I-A [[FIU Golden Panthers football|Golden Panthers football]] team in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/oir/approved_doc_programs_and_20_year_data.xls|title=FIU growth and expansions|accessdate=2007-05-19}} FIU has also increased its academic prestige with the founding of the [[Florida International University School of Architecture|FIU School of Architecture]], [[Florida International University College of Law|FIU College of Law]] and the [[Florida International University College of Medicine|FIU College of Medicine]], as well as the acquisition of the historic [[Wolfsonian-FIU|Wolfsonian-FIU Museum]] in [[Miami Beach]].{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/brief_history4.htm|title=History from 1986 to Today|accessdate=2007-11-09|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070907073744/http%3A//www.fiu.edu/docs/brief_history4.htm |archivedate = September 7, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Florida International University also emphasizes research as a major component of its mission and sponsored research funding (grants and contracts) from external sources for the year 2007-2008 totaled $110 million. FIU has a budget of over $649 million FIU is ranked as a Research University in the High Research Activity category of the Carnegie Foundationâs prestigious classification system.{{Dead link|date=August 2011}} FIU's [[School of Hospitality & Tourism Management]] collaborated with China's [[Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Education]] to work on preparations for the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. FIU was the only university in the United States invited to do so.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinaeconomicreview.com/mba/category/tianjin/|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071006141752/http://www.chinaeconomicreview.com/mba/category/tianjin/|archivedate=2007-10-06|title=FIU Tianjin Center|accessdate=2007-09-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.miamitodaynews.com/news/060921/story7.shtml|title=FIU Hospitality Management Campus in China|accessdate=2007-09-21}} On November 14, 2008, Maidique announced that he would be stepping down and asked FIU's Board of Trustees to begin the search of a new president. He said he would remain president until a new one was found.{{cite web|url=http://fiusm.com/articles/slug-president-maidique|title=President Maidique resigns|accessdate=2008-11-14}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On April 25, 2009, [[Mark B. Rosenberg]] was selected to become FIU's fifth president. He signed a five-year contract with the Board of Trustees.http://news.fiu.edu/?p=4187 On June 12, 2009, the [[FIU College of Medicine]] received the largest donation in the university's history. [[Herbert Wertheim]] donated $20 million to the College of Medicine, to be matched by state funds to create a total donation to the College of Medicine of $40 million. As such, the College of Medicine changed its name to the "Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine".http://news.fiu.edu/?p=4181 ===University presidents=== {| class="wikitable" !President{{cite web|url=http://president.fiu.edu/pastpresidents.html|title=FIU presidents|accessdate=2008-09-23|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080421002518/http%3A//president.fiu.edu/pastpresidents.html |archivedate = April 21, 2008|deadurl=yes}} !Tenure |- |[[Chuck Perry|Charles Perry]]||1965â1976 |- |[[Harold Crosby]]||1976â1979 |- |[[Gregory Baker Wolfe]]||1979â1986 |- |[[Modesto A. Maidique]]||1986â2009 |- |[[Mark B. Rosenberg]]|| since 2009 |} ==Academics== FIU offers 191 academic programs, 74 [[Bachelor's degree|baccalaureate]] programs, 82 [[master's]] programs, 3 [[specialist degree|specialist]] programs, 30 [[doctoral]] programs, and 2 [[professional]] program in 26 colleges and schools. In addition, 97% of the faculty have terminal degrees, and 50% currently have tenure at the university with a student/teacher ratio of 27:1.{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://academic.fiu.edu/docs/colleges.htm|title=FIU Colleges and Schools|accessdate=2009-02-12|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080418184718/http%3A//academic.fiu.edu/docs/colleges.htm |archivedate = April 18, 2008|deadurl=yes}}http://fiu.edu/academics/degree-programs/index.php {| class="toccolours" style="float:center; margin-left:1em; font-size:95%; line-height:1.5em; width:500px;" ! colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" | '''Colleges and schools'''{{cite web | url=http://www.ufl.edu/colleges/ | title=University of Florida Colleges | date=December 26, 2008 | publisher=University of Florida | accessdate=2008-12-26}} |- | colspan="4" |

Ethnic enrollment, 2009{{cite web | title= Enrollment Summary, Fall 2009 | url=http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Headcount/enrollment.pdf |format=PDF| publisher=FIU Office of Planning and Institutional Effectiveness | accessdate=2010-05-07}} ! number |- |[[Asian American|Asian]] | 4% | 1,423 |- |[[Black American|Black (non-Hispanic)]] | 12% | 4,910 |- |[[Hispanic]] (of any race) | 59% | 24,093 |- |Native American | <1% | 86 |- |[[White American|White (non-Hispanic)]] | 17% | 6,299 |- |[[International student|International]], other | 8% | 3,644 |- |Total | 100% | 40,455 |} [[File:FIU walkways.JPG|thumb|right|225px|FIU walkways]] Enrollment for Fall 2010 consisted of 44,010 students, 32,901 [[Undergraduate education|undergraduates]] and 11,109 [[Graduate school|graduate students]], including students enrolled in professional programs.[http://www.fiu.edu/oir/fall_profile/current_fall_profile.pdf] ''Florida International University: Fall 2007 profile'' Retrieved on 11-3-2007. Women accounted for 56% of student enrollment and minorities made up 75% of total enrollment. Enrollment included students from all 50 U.S. states and more than 119 countries.http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Headcount/enrollment.pdf{{cite web|url= http://www.fiu.edu/oir/fb06-07/FIU_Facts_06_07.pdf|format=PDF|title=FIU facts|accessdate=2007-11-02}} The most popular College by enrollment is the [[Florida International University College of Arts and Sciences|College of Arts and Sciences]].[http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/portal/cds_2005-06.htm#B] ''Florida International University: OPIE'' Retrieved on 5-24-2007. The freshman retention rate for 2009 was 83%. The fall 2010 incoming freshman class had an average 3.69 GPA and 1140 SAT score.[http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Admissions/admissions_2010.pdf GPA & SAT for the Fall 2010 incoming class] In 2008, 7% of FIU students were [[international students]]. Of those, the most popular countries of origin were: [[China]] (20%), [[India]] (13%), [[Jamaica]] (10%), [[Venezuela]] (6%), [[Colombia]] (5%), and [[Trinidad and Tobago]] (4%).http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Intl%20Students/Intl_Std_Hcnt.pdf Students from [[New York]], [[New Jersey]], and [[California]] make up the largest states for out-of-state students. Floridians make up 90% of the student population. [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]], [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]], [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach]], [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough]], and [[Orange County, Florida|Orange County]] make up the largest Florida counties for in-state students. [[University Park, Florida|University Park]] accounted for 87% of the student population and 94% of housing students. The [[Biscayne Bay Campus]] accounted for about 13% of the student population, mostly of lower division undergraduates and students of the [[School of Hospitality & Tourism Management]]. Fall 2009, the average age for undergraduates was 23 and 31 for graduate students.[http://www.fiu.edu/oir/fb05-06/enrollment_data_2005.pdf] ''Florida International University: Fall 2005 enrollment data'' Retrieved on 5-24-2007.[http://www.fiu.edu/oir/fall_profile/current_fall_profile.pdf] ''Florida International University: Fall 2007 data'' Retrieved on October 27, 2007. ===Undergraduate admissions=== In 2010 FIU had an admission rate of 39.5% for first-time-in-college freshmen, the lowest in the State University System.{{cite web |url=http://www.flbog.org/resources/factbooks/factbooks.php |title=State University System of Florida Facts and Figures |accessdate= September 16, 2011|publisher=State University System of Florida}} As Miami's public research university, competition to enroll at FIU has heightened as more students apply each year.http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Admissions/admissions_2010.pdf The preliminary Fall 2010 FIU [[freshman]] class had an average [[SAT]] score of 1700, a 25 [[ACT (examination)|ACT]] score and a 3.69 high school [[GPA]]. The freshmen 2010 acceptance rate was 39%. FIU received 15,061 freshmen applications and admitted 5,949, of which 2,338 enrolled.[http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/portal/quickfacts.htm] ''Florida International University: Fall 2010 Quick Facts'' Retrieved on January 30, 2011.
'''FIU graduate admissions'''{{cite web |url=http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Admissions/admissions_09.pdf |format=PDF|title=FIU graduate admission rates|accessdate=2010-03-15 |date=2010-03-15 |work=Official site }} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! !! 2010 !! 2009 !! 2008 !! 2007 |- ! Applicants | 13,619 || 11,987 || 8,923 || 7,574 |- ! Admits | 4,273 || 3,932 || 3,626 || 3,249 |- ! % Admitted | 31.3 || 32.8 || 40.6 || 42.8 |}
===Graduate admissions=== For Fall 2010, 13,619 students applied for graduate admissions throughout the university. Of those, 31% were accepted.http://w3.fiu.edu/irdata/_Fact%20Book/Admissions/admissions_09.pdf The [[Florida International University College of Medicine|Wertheim College of Medicine]] admitted 3.8% of its applicants, and the [[Florida International University College of Law|College of Law]] admitted 19%. Admission to the Wertheim College of Medicine is competitive, and the college has one of the highest number of applicants in the state, greater than the [[University of Florida]]. For Fall 2010, 3,606 students applied for 43 spots.http://news.fiu.edu/2010/07/fiu-herbert-wertheim-college-of-medicine-to-welcome-class-of-2014/ The [[Florida International University School of Architecture|FIU School of Architecture]] is the most competitive in Florida, with the lowest admission rate in the state at 14% (2011).http://soa.fiu.edu/applyarchitecture.htm For Fall 2009, the [[Florida International University School of Architecture|School of Architecture]] received over 1,000 applications for the first-year [[Master of Architecture]] program, with 60 being accepted, giving the School of Architecture a 6% admissions rate. The average high school GPA for the freshman class in the School of Architecture was 3.98, also making it one of the most selective schools at FIU.http://fiu.edu/~soa/ ==Rankings== {{Infobox US university ranking | GUR = | USNWR_NU = | USNWR All Around = | ARWU_W = | ARWU_N = | Forbes = 188 | Newsweek = | THES_W = | THES_N = | CMUP = | Wamo = | Wamo_NU = 121 }} {| class="infobox" style="width: 23em; font-size: 75%;; text-align:left" |- ! colspan="2" style="font-size: 150%; text-align: center;" | Other FIU Rankingshttp://premium.usnews.com/best-colleges/florida-international-university-133951/overall-rankings |- | ''USNWR'' International Business || 16 |- | ''USNWR'' Law || 132 |- | ''USNWR'' Part-time Law || 40 |- | ''USNWR'' Public Affairs || 57 |- | ''USNWR'' Social Work || 71 |} [[File:FIU HLS.JPG|right|thumb|225px|Academic Health Center Buildings, home of the [[Florida International University College of Medicine|Wertheim College of Medicine]] and the [[Florida International University Robert Stempel College of Public Health and Social Work|Robert Stempel College of Public Health and Social Work]].]] In 2011, FIU was ranked in the top 16 nationally amongst universities with the toughest grading system.http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505145_162-37243170/grade-inflation-colleges-with-the-easiest-and-hardest-grades/ FIU is working on a new vision called "FIU in the year 2015: FIU at FIFTY" as part of their 50th anniversary [http://fifty.fiu.edu/ "FIU at Fifty"]. The goal is to make FIU one of the top ten urban-serving public research universities in the country. In 2000, FIU became the youngest university to be awarded a [[Phi Beta Kappa]] chapter, the country's oldest and most distinguished academic honor society. FIU is one of only 78 universities nationwide to hold both designations.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/achievements.htm|title=FIU: Carnegie Foundation rankings and Phi Beta Kappa|accessdate=2008-01-10|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080416223717/http%3A//www.fiu.edu/docs/achievements.htm |archivedate = April 16, 2008|deadurl=yes}} US News and World Report reported that FIU students are among the least indebted college students in the nation, and recognized the university as a "best buy" in higher education.http://www2.fiu.edu/docs/achievements.htm FIU ranked among the best values in public higher education in the country, according to Kiplingerâs Personal Finance magazineâs 2011 survey, "100 Best Values in Public Colleges." FIU is ranked among the top 100 nationally for in-state students and out-of-state students.{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2011/01/05/ucf-no-33-on-kiplingers-best-value.html | date=January 5, 2011 | title=FIU 97th on Kiplinger's best value list}} FIU is ranked 1st in the U.S. for granting bachelor's degrees to minorities, and 9th in granting master's degrees to minorities (among the top 100 universities), according to Diverse Issues in Higher Education, (2010). FIU is also 1st in the nation in awarding science, technology, engineering, and math degrees to minorities. FIU produces over 1,500 minority graduates in those fields annually (2010).http://issuu.com/fiumagazine/docs/finalpdf-winter_2010?mode=embed&layout=http%3A%2F%2Fskin.issuu.com%2Fv%2Flight%2Flayout.xml&showFlipBtn=true From 2007 to 2010, FIU has ranked 1st in Florida's [[State University System of Florida|State University System]] in energy conservation and [[sustainability]].http://news.fiu.edu/2011/02/fiu-no-1-in-sus-in-energy-conservation/ ===College of Business Administration=== [[File:FIU primera casa.JPG|right|thumb|225px|[[Florida International University College of Business Administration|The College of Business Administration]] is ranked in the top 15% of graduate business schools in the U.S. and 1st in [[South Florida]].{{cite web|url=http://wordpress.fiu.edu/news/2008/09/04/fiu-college-of-business-among-the-best-in-us-news-world-report-ranking-for-international-business/|title=Business School rankings|accessdate=2008-09-23}}]] The [[Florida International University College of Business Administration|College of Business Administration]] is among the top 7% of elite business schools worldwide accredited by the AACSB Internationalâ[[The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]].http://business.fiu.edu/Spotlights/recognition.cfm [[Us news|U.S. News & World Report's]] "America's Best Colleges" (2010) ranks the undergraduate international business program 12th best in the nation and ranks the Chapman Graduate School of Business 11th in the nation.{{cite web|url=http://business.fiu.edu|title=FIU Executive MBA program 1st in Florida|accessdate=2007-05-20}} FIU has been ranked in the top 10 every year since 2005.http://business.fiu.edu/ FIU is also the only university in Florida to be ranked in the top 15.http://news.fiu.edu/2009/09/fiu-no-12-in-undergraduate-international-business-in-u-s-news-2010-rankings/ ''[[BusinessWeek]]'' (2008) ranks the College of Business among the top 15% of graduate business schools in the U.S., 1st in [[South Florida]], and in the top 25 among public business schools in the U.S. The Landon Undergraduate School of Business was ranked in the top 5% in the U.S., ranked 8th in the country in the area of "Operations Management", and in the top 20 for "Accounting".{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} ''[[AmÃ©rica EconomÃ­a]]'' ranks the Chapman Graduate School of Business 22nd in the nation.{{cite web|url=http://wordpress.fiu.edu/news/2008/09/22/fiu%e2%80%99s-mba-program-ranked-in-top-25-in-americaeconomia/|title=FIU MBA ranked #22 in the world|accessdate=2008-09-23}} The Financial Times (2008) ranks the Executive MBA in the top 85 MBA programs in the world, and in the top 35 among U.S. Executive MBAs.{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/releases/2007/10-24_executive.htm|title=FIU College of Business amongst world's best programs|accessdate=2007-05-20|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071219172903/http%3A//news.fiu.edu/releases/2007/10-24_executive.htm |archivedate = December 19, 2007|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://rankings.ft.com/rankings/emba/rankings.html|title=FIU MBA program the highest ranked in Florida|accessdate=2007-05-20}}{{cite web|url=http://wordpress.fiu.edu/news/2008/10/31/financial-times-fiu%e2%80%99s-executive-mba-among-the-top-in-the-world/|title=Executive MBA program ranked top 35 in U.S.|accessdate=2008-11-02}} [[Hispanic Business]] (since 1998) and Hispanic Trends (since 2003) have placed the College of Business among the top 25 business schools for Hispanics. In 2008, it was ranked #8.http://business.fiu.edu/newsletters/BusinessNetworks/November2006/mba_rankings.cfm Fortune Small Business recognized the college as among the best in the United States for entrepreneurship in its listing of âAmericaâs Best Colleges for Entrepreneurs,â (August, 2007), in the âCross-Disciplinary/Cross Pollinationâ category. Hispanic Trends ranks the Executive MBA program 8th in its list of the best Executive MBA programs for Hispanics. ===College of Law=== [[File:FIULawRDB.jpg|225px|thumb|right|The [[Florida International University College of Law|FIU College of Law]] has consistently ranked 1st in Florida with the state's highest bar-passing rates (2005, 2007, and 2009), and 1st in the [[MPRE]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sunethics.com/ba-results.htm|title=FIU Law School with highest passing rate in Florida|accessdate=2007-11-22}}]] The [[Florida International University College of Law]] has consistently ranked 1st in the state of Florida with the state's highest bar-passing rates (2005, 2007, and 2009), and 1st in Florida in the Multistate Professional Responsibility Exam at 96% in 2007. In 2006, 2007, and 2009, the [[Florida International University College of Law|College of Law]] was ranked 1st in bar passing rates in Florida and in 2007, the College of Law was also ranked 1st in Florida in the [[Multistate Professional Responsibility Exam]] at 96%.{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/thisweek/2007/10_15_2007.htm|title=FIU Law School, MPRE|accessdate=2008-01-10}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/schools/sfl-fiu-bar-exams-p042609pnapr27,0,6247943.story In July 2008, the College of Law achieved a 90.6% passing rate, which placed it 2nd among Florida's ten law schools. In February 2009, the College of Law achieved a 81.5% passing rate, which placed it 1st among Florida's ten law schools. In 2010, the FIU College of Law was ranked among the Top 10 Best Value schools by The National Jurist.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaljurist.com/content/best-value-law-schools|title= Best Value Law Schools|accessdate=2010-10-12}} The Best Value rating was based on three criteria: bar passage rate, average indebtedness after graduation, and employment nine months after graduation. FIU College of Law also ranked 3rd amongst Florida schools for the scholarly impact of its faculties, behind [[University of Florida]] and [[Florida State University]]. According to the Leiter Rankings, the College of Law has already made a scholarly impact that dramatically outpaces its academic reputation.{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/2010/10/fiu-law-ranked-top-10-best-value-school/|title=FIU Law ranked Top 10 Best Value School|accessdate=2010-10-12}} ===Other colleges and schools=== The ''Journal of Criminal Justice'' ranks the Criminal Justice program 10th in the U.S. (November 2007){{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/trustees/pdf/2007/General/11-16-07_FB.pdf|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080216105953/http://www.fiu.edu/trustees/pdf/2007/General/11-16-07_FB.pdf|archivedate=2008-02-16|format=PDF|title=FIU Board of Trustees meeting November 2007|accessdate=2007-12-13}} The [[Creative Writing]] program is ranked among the top ten in the country by "Who Runs American Literature?".http://casgroup.fiu.edu/english/pages.php?id=105 The [[School of Hospitality & Tourism Management]] is one of the nationâs top programs. The School of [[Hospitality management studies|Hospitality Management]] is recognized by industry leaders as one of the nation's top five hospitality management programs. Faculty of the Ph.D. program in social welfare rank 4th in the United States in their scholarly accomplishment, according to Academic Analytics. FIU faculty were the only social work faculty in Florida to rank in the Top 10. (December 2007){{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/releases/2007/12-21_excellence.htm|title=Social welfare Ph.D. faculty rank #4 in U.S.|accessdate=2007-12-13|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080105033453/http%3A//news.fiu.edu/releases/2007/12-21_excellence.htm |archivedate = January 5, 2008|deadurl=yes}} ==Campus== Florida International University has two major campuses in Miami, the main campus, [[University Park, FL|University Park]] and its regional campus, the [[Biscayne Bay Campus]], as well as several branch campuses and research facilities throughout [[South Florida]], in [[Tianjin, China]], and in [[Nervi]] and [[Genoa, Italy]].{{Dead link|date=August 2011}} ===University Park (Modesto A. Maidique Campus)=== [[File:FIU Campus.JPG|225px|left|thumb|Turtle Pond]] [[File:DM square.JPG|right|thumb|225px|View of the campus towards Primera Casa and DeuxiÃ¨me Maison]] [[File:FIUgreen.JPG|right|thumb|225px|View of the campus towards the College of Nursing and Health Sciences Building.]] The main campus, University Park, renamed Modesto Maidique Campus in 2009,{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/2009/06/fiuâs-university-park-renamed-modesto-a-maidique-campus/|title=FIUâs University Park renamed Maidique Campus}} encompasses 344 acres (1.4 kmÂ²) in the Miami neighborhood of [[University Park, Florida|University Park]], (from which the area derives its name). University Park houses almost all of the university's colleges and schools as well as all the administrative offices and main university facilities. University Park is also home to the Ronald Reagan Presidential House, the home of FIU's president, the Wertheim Performing Arts Center, the [[Frost Art Museum]], the International Hurricane Research Center, and the university's athletic facilities such as [[FIU Stadium]], [[U.S. Century Bank Arena]], and the [[University Park Stadium]]. Located five blocks north of University Park, is the 38-acre (145,000 m2) [[Engineering Center]] which houses a part of the [[Florida International University College of Engineering and Computing|College of Engineering and Computing]] and is the home of FIU's [[Motorola]] [[Nanotechnology|Nanofabrication]] Research Facility. The Engineering Center is serviced by the CATS Shuttle, FIU's student buses, which run throughout the day on weekdays connecting the two parts of campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.cec.fiu.edu/CEC_About.htm|title=FIU Engineering Center|accessdate=2007-11-10|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071213055332/http%3A//www.cec.fiu.edu/CEC_About.htm |archivedate = December 13, 2007|deadurl=yes}} ====University Park history==== Construction on the campus began in 1965 with the complete destruction of [[Tamiami Airport]] in 1969. At the time, very little was located around FIU, and the campus was referred to as University Park. As Miami grew west, the area came to be known as University Park after the university's campus name. Until the early-1990s, aerial pictures of the campus clearly revealed the features of the airport that used to occupy the land until 1969. [[Construction]] has removed all of these features, and only the University Tower remains as a memory of the university's past.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/fiuvideos/other1.html|title=History of FIU video|accessdate=2007-11-10|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071017121815/http%3A//www.fiu.edu/docs/fiuvideos/other1.html |archivedate = October 17, 2007|deadurl=yes}} University Park is a lush, heavily vegetated campus, with many lakes and nature preserves, as well as an arboretum and has over 90 buildings. As of late 2009, current construction at University Park includes the Nursing and Health Sciences Building, the School of International and Public Affairs Building, and a fifth parking garage.{{cite web|url=http://fiusm.com/articles/slug-stadium|title=FIU Stadium construction information|accessdate=2008-09-23}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On June 12, 2009, FIU's Board of Trustees voted unanimously to rename the University Park campus to the Modesto Maidique Campus. However, the change created a large backlash from the FIU community, as many felt it unfitting to name the campus after him. A campaign by FIU students and alumni was created to revert the name change, and to keep the name University Park. A [[Facebook]] group, "No to Maidique's Campus" with over 2,000 supporters has made national news, in many newspapers, TV news stations, and collegiate magazines, supporting to keep the name "University Park".http://fiusm.com/news/2009/6/20/students-rally-online-against-renaming-of-campus ====Main University Park buildingshttp://campusmaps.fiu.edu/http://facilities.fiu.edu/documents/planning/Building_History.pdf==== {| style="border:1px solid #ddd; background:#fefefe; padding:5px; margin:5px;" | *Campus Support Complex, 1999 *Carlos Finlay Elementary School *Chemistry & Physics Building, 1990 *College of Business Complex, 2008 *College of Health Building, 1989 *DeuxiÃ¨me Maison, 1973 *[[Engineering Center]] *Engineering and Computer Sciences Building, 1990 *Everglades Hall, 2002 *[[FIU Stadium]], 1995 *[[Frost Art Museum]], 1977 (new building: 2007) *Graham Center, 1974 | style="width:80px;"| | *Green Library, 1975 *Health and Life Sciences I and II, 2000 *Labor Center, 1994 *Lakeview Hall North and South, 2006 *Management and Advanced Research Center, 2002 *[[National Hurricane Center]], 1967 *Nursing and Health Sciences Building, 2009 *Owa Ehan, 1975 *Panther Hall, 1996 *Paul Cejas School of Architecture Building, 2003 *Primera Casa, 1969 *Rafael Diaz-Balart Law Building, 2006 | style="width:80px;"| | *Recreation Center, 2005 *Ronald Reagan House, 2001 *Ryder Business Building, 1992 *School of International and Public Affairs Building, 2010 *University Health Services Complex, 1992 *University Park Apartments, 1986 *University Park Towers, 2000 *[[U.S. Century Bank Arena]], 1986 *Viertes Haus, 1975 *Wertheim Conservatory, 1991 *Wertheim Performing Arts Center, 1996 *Ziff Education Building, 1995 |} ===Biscayne Bay Campus=== [[File:BBCCampus.jpg|thumb|right|225px|FIU's regional campus in [[North Miami]], the [[Biscayne Bay Campus]], opened in 1977.]] [[File:Brickell1.JPG|thumb|right|225px|[[Brickell Avenue|1101 Brickell Avenue]], home of FIU's [[Downtown Miami]] Campus]] The [[Biscayne Bay Campus]] in [[North Miami]] is FIU's second-largest campus. It was opened in 1977 by [[Harold Crosby]] and occupies about 200 acres (809,000 mÂ²), directly on the bay and adjacent to the [[Oleta River State Park]], with which FIU has a research partnership. Access to these resources inspired the creation of a [[marine biology]] program on the Biscayne Bay Campus, which has become one of the university's most recognized programs. The Biscayne Bay Campus also houses the [[School of Hospitality & Tourism Management]], one of the nation's top programs,{{cite web|url=http://hospitality.fiu.edu/|title=FIU Hospitality Management, top U.S. program|accessdate=2008-01-10}} the School of Journalism and Mass Communication, the Aquatic Center, and the Kovens Conference Center. The Golden Panther Express, FIU's student buses, connect the main campus and the Biscayne Bay Campus throughout the day on weekdays.{{cite web|url=http://parking.fiu.edu/bus_schedule.htm|title=Golden Panther Express schedules|accessdate=2007-05-19}} ===Regional campuses=== FIU also has other smaller regional campuses located throughout South Florida in both [[Miami-Dade County]] and [[Broward County]], serving the local communities in research, continuing studies, and in culture. In Broward County, there is the FIU Pines Center in [[Pembroke Pines, Florida|Pembroke Pines]], opened to satisfy the demand from Broward County residents. This center serves mostly night students in programs within the [[Florida International University College of Business Administration|College of Business Administration]]. In [[Miami-Dade County]], there are four regional FIU facilities, the [[Downtown Miami]] Campus, the [[Wolfsonian-FIU Museum]] in [[Miami Beach]] ([[Washington Avenue (Miami Beach)|Washington Avenue]] and 10th St), the [[Florida Memorial University|FIU-Florida Memorial]] research center in [[Miami Gardens]], and a research site in [[Homestead, Florida|Homestead]]. ====Downtown Miami Campus==== FIU has a campus on [[Brickell Avenue]] in [[Downtown Miami]] at 1101 Brickell Avenue dubbed "FIU Downtown on Brickell". FIU's College of Business Administration has had classes at the Macy's Building on [[Flagler Street]] and the Metropolitan Center had offices at 150 SE 2nd Ave since 2004. Starting in August 2011, FIU is expanding its Downtown campus to 1101 Brickell with the expansion of course offerings for the College of Business Administration and the School of International and Public Affairs, as well as with FIU's research center, the Metropolitan Center. Most programs in Downtown are graduate-level evening courses geared for Downtown professionals and residents.{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2011/03/23/fiu-signs-12m-lease-in-downtown-miami.html | date=March 23, 2011 | title=FIU signs $12M lease in downtown Miami}} As of Spring 2011, there were approximately 500 students enrolled at the Downtown campus, with plans to grow the campus to over 2,000 students by 2021.http://news.fiu.edu/2011/03/fiu-to-open-brickell-ave-facility-in-fall-2011-with-a-focus-on-international-leadership/ ===International campuses=== [[File:Tuc.jpg|225px|right|thumb|[[Florida International University Tianjin Center|FIU Tianjin Center]] in [[Tianjin, China]].]] FIU also has international campuses in Asia and Europe. The [[Wolfsonian-FIU Museum]] has a regional facility in [[Nervi]], Italy, the [[Florida International University School of Architecture|School of Architecture]] has facilities in [[Genoa, Italy]] for FIU's upper-division and graduate Architecture students, and the [[Florida International University Tianjin Center]] in China, from which a branch of the [[School of Hospitality & Tourism Management]] operates. The Tianjin Center was constructed as a cooperative venture with the local municipal government and was opened in the Summer of 2006. FIU has also exchanged agreements with the [[American University]] in [[Dubai]] so that FIU students can now take a semester abroad in Dubai.http://news.fiu.edu/2009/08/fiu-establishes-exchange-agreement-with-american-university-in-dubai/ ===Student housing=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:400px; float:left;" ! FIU residence halls{{cite web | title= FIU Housing | url=http://www.housing.fiu.edu/Buildings/index.html | publisher=FIU Office of Housing and Residential Life | accessdate=2008-09-16}} ! Year built ! Room
capacity ! Accommodations |- | Bay Vista Hall (Biscayne Bay Campus) | 1984 | 300 | All students |- | University Park Apartments | 1986 | 584 | All students (inc. graduate and married housing) |- | Panther Hall | 1996 | 400 | Freshmen (inc. Honors College freshmen) |- | University Park Towers | 2000 | 500 | All students (inc. graduate, Law and Medical housing) |- | Everglades Hall | 2002 | 400 | All students (primarily sophomores) |- | Lakeview Hall North | 2006 | 400 | All students |- | Lakeview Hall South | 2006 | 425 | Freshmen (inc. Honors College and Architecture freshmen) |- | Total | - | 3,009 students | - |} [[File:FIU Towers.JPG|thumb|University Park Towers, graduate student and upperclassmen apartments.]] Florida International University's student housing facilities are managed by the Office of Housing and Residential Life and are available on both the [[University Park, FL|main campus]] and the [[Biscayne Bay Campus]]. Currently, there are 3,009 beds distributed throughout 10 apartment buildings and 6 residence halls. At University Park, these are the University Park Apartments, Panther Hall, the University Park Towers, Everglades Hall, Lakeview Hall North, and Lakeview Hall South. At the Biscayne Bay Campus, housing is available in Bay Vista Hall.{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~housing/about.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070510021645/http://www.fiu.edu/~housing/about.html|archivedate=2007-05-10|title=Housing and Residential Life|accessdate=2007-11-09}} Together, approximately 7% of FIU's student population lives on-campus in student housing (not including Greek housing). The Office of Housing and Residential Life also offers optional communities in the residence halls. These communities include the Architecture and Arts Community, for students majoring in Architecture or art-related majors, Honors Place for Honors College students, F.Y.R.S.T. (First Year Residents Succeeding Together) for all freshmen in any major, F.Y.R.S.T. Explore, for undecided freshmen, Leader's in Residence for students interested in civic service and leadership opportunities and the Law Community for College of Law students.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~housing/livingandlearning.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070321000602/http://www.fiu.edu/~housing/livingandlearning.html|archivedate=2007-03-21|title=Residence hall communities|accessdate=2007-11-10}} As of 2011, plans are underway for two new residence halls for 1,240 students, called "Parkview Housing" to be built on the Panther Hall parking lot, north of [[FIU Stadium]]. Parkview Housing will be built in two phases in two separate buildings, each housing 620 and 600 students respectively, to be completed by Fall 2013 and Fall 2016.http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT_889/BT-889%20Parkview%20Housing%20AE%20Project%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf ===Libraries=== [[File:FIU Green Library.JPG|225px|right|thumb|Green Library, is one of the largest libraries in the Southeastern U.S. and is the largest building on-campus.]] FIU has six libraries, Green Library, FIU's main library; the Glenn Hubert Library (Biscayne Bay Campus), the Wolfsonian Library, the Engineering Library, the Law Library, and the Medical Library. ====Green Library==== Green Library is FIU's main library, and is the largest building on-campus, and one of the largest libraries in the Southeastern United States.{{cite web|url=http://library.fiu.edu/files/news/21stcentury.html|title=FIU Library -- Library for the 21st Century|accessdate=2008-12-19}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Originally built in the late 1960s, the Green Library was expanded by the architecture firm M. C. Harry & Associates, Inc. in the early 1990s to its current eight floors, with a capacity to expand to a total of 15 floors if expansions are necessary. This eight floor structure was built around the original three-story 1960s library, while it was still in use.http://www.mcharry.com/html/3-fiu-lib.htm The first floor of the building has numerous offices, classrooms, auditorium spaces, a snack stop, and a [[Starbucks]].{{cite web|url=http://www.campusdish.com/en-US/CSS/FloridaInternationalUniv/Locations/MMC-GreenLibrary.htm|title=CampusDish at Florida International University-Green Library|accessdate=2010-11-07}} The second floor has the reference section, cartography, circulation, and numerous computer and printing labs. The third and fourth floors are the home of the Medical Library, as well as a resource center for students of the Honors College, special collections section, archives, and study lounges. The fifth floor is the home of the School of Architecture Library, as well as the music and audiovisual sections. The sixth, seventh, and eighth floors are strictly quiet floors, and contain the general collection floors, numerous student study lounges, and library administration offices.http://library.fiu.edu/AboutUs/FloorPlans/tabid/180/Default.aspxhttp://medicine.fiu.edu/library.php ====Law and Engineering libraries==== Other libraries at University Park include the three-story [[Florida International University College of Law|College of Law]] Library in Diaz-Balart Hall, the Engineering Library, and the Medical Library. The Law Library opened in 2002, and has three floors, with all three holding the library's general collection. The third floor has a two-story, quiet reading room, as well as numerous study lounges. Although the Law Library is restricted to Law students, other students may use the library for research purposes.http://law.lawnet.fiu.edu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26&Itemid=644 The Engineering Library is located on the second floor of the main building of the Engineering Center.http://library.fiu.edu/AboutUs/DepartmentsServices/EngineeringLibraryServices/tabid/292/Default.aspx ====Medical Library==== [http://medlib.fiu.edu The FIU Medical Library] opened in August 2009 at the same time as the opening of the [[FIU Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine|Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine]]. The Medical Library offers a rich array of resources, services, and instructional support to advance the teaching and learning, discovery, and healthcare programs of the Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine and is currently located on the third floor of Green Library building. Future construction of buildings for the College of Medicine will include a new space for the Medical Library outside of Green Library.http://medlib.fiu.edu ====Wolfsonian and Glenn Hubert libraries==== The Wolfsonian Library is located at the [[Wolfsonian-FIU Museum]] in [[South Beach]], on the corner of [[Washington Avenue (Miami Beach)|Washington Avenue]] and 10th Street.http://www.wolfsonian.org/collections/c9/main.html The collection focuses exclusively on [[architecture]], [[art]], [[design]], and [[history]] of the [[Western World]] from 1885 to 1945. The library serves mostly as a [[research library]] with an extensive collection of [[primary sources]]. For students, prior approval from the staff is needed to enter the library. The Glenn Hubert Library, previously named the 'Biscayne Bay Library', is the main, and sole library at the [[Biscayne Bay Campus]]. Together, the entire FIU university-wide Library holdings include over 2,097,207 volumes, 52,511 current serials, 3,587,663 microform units, and 163,715 audio visual units.{{cite web|url=http://library.fiu.edu/files/about/annual%20report%20accountability%20report%2005%20-%2006.pdf|format=PDF|title=FIU Libraries|accessdate=2007-11-09|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071129064451/http%3A//library.fiu.edu/files/about/annual%2520report%2520accountability%2520report%252005%2520-%252006.pdf |archivedate = November 29, 2007|deadurl=yes}} ===International Hurricane Research Center=== [[File:FIU Everglades.JPG|right|thumb|225px|Everglades Hall, upperclassmen apartments.]] The International Hurricane Research Center (IHRC) is the nationâs only university-based research facility dedicated to mitigating the damage tropical storms inflict on people, the economy, and the environment. The IHRC is home to four institutes: the Laboratory for Coastal Research; the Laboratory for Social Science Research; the Laboratory for Insurance, Financial & Economic Research; and the Laboratory for Wind Engineering Research, as well as the FIU Wall of Wind. This first-of-its-kind testing system consists of a series of large industrial fans powered by race car engines. It produces a wind field equivalent to a Category Four [[hurricane]].{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/releases/2007/05-30_damageresearch.htm|title=International Hurricane Research Center|accessdate=2007-06-01|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070602141001/http%3A//news.fiu.edu/releases/2007/05-30_damageresearch.htm |archivedate = June 2, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Not to be confused with the [[National Hurricane Center]] (also located at University Park), the IHRC is located on the western side of the campus. ===Construction and expansion=== In the early 2000s, emphasis at FIU was placed on growth in degree programs and student enrollment. Since 2005 however, student enrollment has been capped and emphasis is now being placed on improving the quality of the existing academic programs. With the addition of the [[Florida International University College of Medicine|College of Medicine]], the demand for facilities and classroom space has greatly increased.{{cite web|url=http://facilities.fiu.edu/Planning/SelectionProcess.htm|title=Florida International University Facilities Management|accessdate=2007-11-10}} Future projects and/or buildings under construction include: ====Construction: 2009-2010==== *FIU Stadium Field House - completed in July 2009 *College of Nursing and Health Sciences Building - completed in December 2009{{cite web|url=http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT-833%20CMFACTSHT%20NURSING%20REVISED.pdf|format=PDF|title=College of Nursing and Health Sciences Building construction information|accessdate=2008-10-08}} *School of International and Public Affairs Building - broke ground in December 2008, to be finished by late 2010, designed by [[Arquitectonica]]{{cite web|url=http://international.fiu.edu/pg.php?News1|title=FIU International Studies|accessdate=2007-09-21|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080213142630/http%3A//international.fiu.edu/pg.php%3FNews1 |archivedate = February 13, 2008|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT-835%20CM%20LEGAL%20AD.pdf|format=PDF|title=International Studies Building construction|accessdate=2008-09-23}} *PG5 Market Station- completed in August 2010- includes a new retail/restaurant area with fast food outlets{{cite web|url=http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT%20865-875%20CM%20Project%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf|format=PDF|title=Parking Garage V construction information|accessdate=2008-10-08}} *Renovations of the Graham Center- completed in August 2010, will include: expanded food, drink and video game outlets, an expanded outdoor seating area, expanded bookstore cafÃ©, and a renovated bookstore with a larger Panthers merchandise area ====Construction: 2011-onward==== [[File:MiamiMetroBus.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Miami-Dade Transit]] [[Miami-Dade Transit#Metrobus|Metrobus]] serve FIU's campuses, and connect University Park to [[Downtown Miami]]]] *Wells Fargo Bank - Located in Gold Garage. Opened July 18th 2011. *Ambulatory Care Center (Stempel Complex) - broke ground in July 2009, to be completed by 2011 *Expansion of U.S. Century Bank Arena- plans underway for a 2011 construction *Expansion to [[FIU Stadium]] - Expansion to capacitate 45,000 fans to be done in four separate phases (Phase I and II have been completed, Phase III and IV are projected to be completed from around 2011 to 2013) *Graduate Housing- 400-bed residence hall was to have begun Summer 2011 but postponed indefinitely.{{cite web|url=http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT-892%20Legal%20Ad.pdf|format=PDF|title=New graduate housing construction|accessdate=2008-09-23}}{{cite web|url=http://facilities.fiu.edu/projects/BT-892%20Draft%20Program%20_Architects%20Version_%2011-5-08.pdf|format=PDF|title=Graduate Housing information|accessdate=2008-10-07}} *Alumni Center- funding plans underway ===Campus transportation=== [[Miami-Dade Transit]] serves University Park with [[Miami-Dade Transit#Metrobus|Metrobus]] lines 8, 11, 24, and 71. Metrobus lines 75 and 135 serve the Biscayne Bay Campus.http://www.miamidade.gov/transit/metrobus.asp Bus lines 8, 11 and the 24 directly connect FIU with [[Downtown Miami]]. Two distinct FIU-operated bus lines are available. The CATS Shuttle runs between University Park and the Engineering Center, and the Golden Panther Express, from University Park to the Biscayne Bay Campus. The CATS Shuttle connects University Park from the Graham Center bus stop and the Engineering and Computer Sciences Building, to the [[Engineering Center]] on [[Flagler Street]] and 107th Avenue. The CATS Shuttle is free and runs roughly every 30 minutes between 7am to 10pm Monday through Friday. The Golden Panther Express connects the Biscayne Bay Campus to University Park. It runs from 7am to 11pm Monday through Thursday, 7am to approximately 8pm on Fridays, and costs $2.50 each way. The Golden Panther Express departs from the Graham Center bus stop at the main campus, and the Academic 1 bus stop at the Biscayne Bay Campus.http://parking.fiu.edu/bus_schedule.htm ==Student life== ===Greek life=== [[Image:FIU Fiji House.jpg|thumb|right|225px| The [[Phi Gamma Delta]] "Fiji" Fraternity House]] [[Image:FIU frathouse.JPG|thumb|right|225px|The [[Pi Kappa Alpha]] Fraternity House]] FIU has over 30 fraternities and sororities divided into four governing councils: the [[North-American Interfraternity Conference|Interfraternity Council (IFC)]], the [[National Panhellenic Conference|Panhellenic Council (PC)]], the [[National Pan-Hellenic Council|National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC)]], and the [[National Multicultural Greek Council|Multicultural Greek Council (MGC)]]. The [[Order of Omega]], a Greek honor society, has had a chapter at the university since 1991 and represents the academic top 3% of FIU Greeks.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~greeks/|title=Greek Life at FIU|accessdate=2008-05-12}} The Interfraternity Council (IFC) comprises 13 fraternities. The Panhellenic Council (PC) is made up of 7 sororities. The National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) comprises 8 historically black organizations, (4 fraternities and 4 sororities). The Multicultural Greek Council (MGC) consists of 7 cultural organizations for Latinos, Asians, and South Asians, (4 fraternities and 3 sororities).{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~greeks/ifc.html|title=Interfraternity Council at FIU|accessdate=2008-05-12}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~greeks/pc.html|title=Panhellenic Council at FIU|accessdate=2008-05-12}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~greeks/mgc.html|title=Multicultural Greek Council at FIU|accessdate=2008-05-12}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| |} ===Student media=== {{Main|The Beacon (Florida International University)|Radiate FM}} [[File:FIU Lakeview.JPG|right|thumb|225px|Lakeview Hall North and South residence halls. 14% of FIU students live in on-campus housing.]] Student Media is the umbrella organization for [[The Beacon (Florida International University)|The Beacon]], the student-run newspaper; FIUSM.com, the student-run news and media website; and [[Radiate FM]], the student-run radio station. Each organization's directors are selected by the Student Media board on a yearly basis. ''[[The Beacon (Florida International University)|The Beacon]]'' is the FIU [[student newspaper]] since 1965. ''The Beacon'' is published thrice weekly in a [[Compact (newspaper)|compact format]] during the Fall and Spring semesters (Monday, Wednesday and Friday) and once a week on Wednesday during the Summer. It is split into five unique sections, ''News'', reporting a mix of university, local and national events, ''At the Bay'' for news on the Biscayne Bay Campus, ''Sports'', ''Opinion'' and ''Life!'' ''The Beacon'' is available free campus-wide in the residence halls, the Graham Center and all campus buildings.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiusm.com/|title=The Beacon, student newspaper of FIU|accessdate=2007-05-19}} ''FIUSM.com'' is the FIU student-run media website since 2008. FIUSM.com publishes content generated by the Student Media team, including text, audio, and video.{{cite web|url=http://fiusm.com/articles/3634|title=Radiate FM, The Beacon launch new Web site for FIU community|accessdate=2008-08-12}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} [[WRGP|Radiate FM]] is FIU's student-run radio station since 1984.{{cite web|url=http://wrgp.fiu.edu/|title=WRGP Radiate FM, FIU student radio|accessdate=2007-05-19}} It broadcasts on 95.3 MHz at the University Park Campus and on 96.9 MHz at the Biscayne Bay Campus. The signal originates in [[Homestead, Florida|Homestead]] on 88.1 MHz and a [[broadcast translator]] rebroadcasts Radiate FM's signal to the University Park Campus and later again translated to the Biscayne Bay Campus.{{cite web|url=http://wrgp.fiu.edu/about.htm|title=History of WRGP Radiate FM|accessdate=2007-11-10}} ===Arts and culture=== {{See also|Frost Art Museum|Wolfsonian-FIU}} [[File:Frost Art Museum.jpg|225px|thumb|left|[[Frost Art Museum]]]] FIU has two museums, the [[Frost Art Museum]] and the historic [[Wolfsonian-FIU Museum]]. The Frost Art Museum is located on campus and was opened in 1977 as The Art Museum at Florida International University as a student gallery. Today, the Frost Art Museum features collections of both Latin American and 20th century American art.{{cite web|url=http://thefrost.fiu.edu/museum_history.htm|title=Frost Art Museum|accessdate=2008-09-24}} The Wolfsonian-FIU Museum is located in [[Miami Beach]] and promotes the collection, preservation and understanding of decorative art and [[design]] from the period from 1885 to 1945.{{cite web|url=http://www.wolfsonian.org/visitus/history/index.html|title=Wolfsonian-FIU Museum|accessdate=2008-09-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/cultural_life.htm|title=Arts and Culture at FIU|accessdate=2007-11-10}} FIU also has the country's largest university sculpture collection, named the Martin Z. Margulies Family Collection, with over 80 such sculptures around campus.http://www.fiu.edu/docs/brief_history4.htm {{Wayback|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/brief_history4.htm|date =20070907073744|bot=DASHBot}} Many different art structures, statues, paintings and mosaics can be seen throughout campus in gardens, buildings, walkways, and on walls.{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/releases/2002/11-19_weymouth.htm|title=Frost Art Museum|accessdate=2007-11-22|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060901184049/http%3A//news.fiu.edu/releases/2002/11-19_weymouth.htm |archivedate = September 1, 2006|deadurl=yes}} (dead link) The School of Theatre and Dance produces a wide variety of live student performances, and the School of Music presents an annual fall series of concerts that showcase talent in a variety of genres. The festival features FIU musicians as well as distinguished visiting performers. Many plays, musicals, concerts, operas, and dance shows are produced each year, through the School of Theatre, Dance, & Speech Communication at FIU's Wertheim Performing Arts Center.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~thedan/theatre/playing.htm|title=School of Theatre and Dance|accessdate=2007-11-10|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071230041512/http%3A//www.fiu.edu/%7Ethedan/theatre/playing.htm |archivedate = December 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}} FIU annually hosts the [[Food Network South Beach Wine & Food Festival]] in [[South Beach]] through the [[School of Hospitality & Tourism Management]]. The festival is one of the major culinary events in the nation and an event that showcases the talents of the world's most renowned wine and spirits producers, chefs and culinary personalities.{{cite web|url=http://www.sobewineandfoodfest.com/2008/index.php|title=FIU's South Beach Wine & Food Festival|accessdate=2007-11-10}} ===Student Government Association=== [[File:FIU wow.JPG|right|225px|thumb|The Walk on Water race held annually by the [[Florida International University School of Architecture|School of Architecture]].]] The Student Government Association presides over and funds the over 300 student clubs and organizations and [[honor societies]] at the university and has an operating budget of over $11 million.{{cite web|url=http://wuc.fiu.edu/Default.aspx?PageContentMode=1&tabid=229|title=Student Government Association Activities and Service Fees Budget 2007- 2008|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-01-01}} The Student Government Association is split into three branches, with the Executive, a Legislative Student Senate, and Judicial Supreme Court. Due to the unique nature of a multi-campus university, the President of Modesto Maidique Campus (University Park) serves as the Student Representative on the University's Board of Trustees, the current President and Trustee is Patrick O'Keefe, while the current president for the Biscayne Bay Campus is Denise Halpin who also serves as a member of the Foundation Board. [[File:FIU Rec Center.JPG|right|225px|thumb|Recreation Center]] The Student Government contains five separate governing councils- the Student Programming Council, the Council for Student Organizations, which represents the over 300 student clubs and organizations, the Homecoming Council, Black Student Union, and Panther Power, the student spirit group.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~sga/index2.htm|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070402235102/http://www.fiu.edu/~sga/index2.htm|archivedate=2007-04-02|title=FIU student spirit organizations|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-06-01}} The Panther Power group can be seen in all [[Golden Panthers]] athletic events along with the Golden Panthers Band, the Golden Dazzlers dance team and the Golden Panthers cheerleaders.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~rage/index.htm|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070626213801/http://www.fiu.edu/~rage/index.htm|archivedate=2007-06-26|title=Panther Rage, largest spirit group|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-06-01}} In 2004, [[MTV]]'s [[mtvU|Campus Invasion Tour]] was held at FIU, bringing numerous bands such as [[Hoobastank]] to FIU.http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1485256/20040223/hoobastank.jhtml ===Order of the Torch=== The Order of the Torch is a semi-secret honorary leadership society akin to other secret societies in the state such as [[Florida Blue Key]] at the [[University of Florida]], and the [[Iron Arrow Honor Society]] at the [[University of Miami]]. The organization is rumored to have been founded in 2003 as a way of organizing student leadership to restructure student life to mirror that of a traditional university. Members now include students, faculty, staff and community members, including FIU alumni [[Miami-Dade County]] Mayor [[Carlos Alvarez (mayor)|Carlos Alvarez]] (class of 1974). Top leadership in Student Government, Homecoming, and the most elite campus fraternal organizations, rank among its members. ===Traditions=== ====Spirit traditions==== [[File:FIU OE.JPG|thumb|right|225px|Green Library and Owa Ehan.]] FIU has many traditions from student spirit groups, alumni association events and student spirit events. Panther Rage, one of FIU's largest student spirit groups are seen at all the athletics events.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/~camplife/rage.html|title=Panther Rage and Campus Life|accessdate=2008-09-23}} FIU also holds many Golden Panther spirit events throughout the year. Some of these include, Panther Camp held in the Summer prior to the Fall term for incoming freshmen, where students spend a weekend in a [[retreat (spiritual)|retreat]] center learning all the traditional Golden Panther cheers, chants, traditions meeting other incoming students. Started in 2006, Panther Camp has grown quickly in popularity from only 25 participants in 2006 to over 120 participants in 2007. In 2008, Panther Camp expanded to two camps with a combined total of 240 freshman participants.{{cite web|url=http://news.fiu.edu/fiumag/Winter_07/news_03.htm|title=Panther Camp|accessdate=2008-09-23}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Panther Camp is expected to grow in size for Summer 2010, as the waiting list has continued to double from year to year. Freshmen who participate are more likely to get involved in Student Life than other students.http://fiusm.com/news/2009/8/28/-88 Week of Welcome, usually held the first or second week of the Fall semester holds many spirit events, such as Trail of the Torch. Trail of the Torch is another university tradition that has continued to grow annually, where a [[pep rally]] is held in the Housing Quad with music, food, giveaways and dancing. After the pep rally, the torch of knowledge is lit and blue and gold candles are distributed to the crowd for the procession around the campus, trailing the torch from the Housing Quad to the torch in front of the Primera Casa building. Rage Week and [[Homecoming]] Week are other major back-to-back spirit weeks held in the Fall semester. They include the Homecoming Parade, Greek Row parties, Homecoming football game, Blue/Gold Party, pep rallies and other Panther Rage events.{{cite web|url=http://media.www.beaconnewspaper.com/media/storage/paper540/news/2006/08/28/News/Welcome.Week.Starts.New.Year-2240354.shtml|title=Week of Welcome|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-11-10}} ====Alma Mater==== [[File:FIU Stadium2.JPG|thumb|right|225px|[[Golden Panthers]] fans at [[FIU Stadium]].]]
'''[[Alma Mater|FIU Alma Mater]]'''http://www.fiualumni.com/NetCommunity/Page.aspx?pid=593
''Hail to thee dear FIU
''With voices true we pledge to thee
''All our love and our devotion
''Humble faith and loyalty
''We will strive for understanding
''and for peace and unity
''We will search for truth and wisdom
''We will always honor thee
''FIU alma mater
''Hail hail to thee''
====Superstitions and legends==== There are many other traditions at FIU that are not spirit-related. The large cube in front of DeuxiÃ¨me Maison is said to give good luck in exams and tests and thus is spun by hundreds of students every semester. During [[final exams]], a line forms around the cube with people waiting to be able to spin the cube for good luck on their exams. The "Kissing Bridge" tradition in Turtle Pond in between the Ryder Business Building and Green Library. The tradition is that if you kiss someone on the bridge you will stay with them forever. The top floor of Green Library is said to be haunted; students have reported a friendly ghost that wanders the halls minutes before the library closes at night.http://fiualumni.com/NetCommunity/Page.aspx?pid=301 Another [[superstition]] is that if a student steps on the seal engraved in front of the Graham Center and in the WUC at the Biscayne Bay Campus, the university's student union, it is said that they will delay their graduation for many years, or never graduate at all, and thus even on crowded days, students go around the seal to avoid stepping on it.{{cite web|url=http://fiualumni.com/traditions.htm|title=FIU traditions|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-11-10|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071013173249/http%3A//fiualumni.com/traditions.htm |archivedate = October 13, 2007|deadurl=yes}} (dead link) ==Athletics== [[File:FIUGoldenPanthers2008.png|right|thumb|The [[FIU Golden Panthers]] athletic logo.[http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/colleges/fiu/story/560172.html Golden Panthers unveil new logo - 6 June '2008 - MiamiHerald.com]{{Dead link|date=October 2008}}]] {{Main|FIU Golden Panthers}} {{See also|FIU Golden Panthers football}} [[File:FIU Stadium.JPG|left|225px|thumb|The [[FIU Golden Panthers football|Golden Panthers football team]] plays at the on-campus [[FIU Stadium]].]] Florida International University has seventeen varsity sports teams, named the [[Golden Panthers]]. The Golden Panthers' athletic colors are blue and gold, and compete in the [[Division I (NCAA)|NCAA Division I]] as part of the [[Sun Belt Conference]] in all sports except for men's [[soccer]] (which competes in [[Conference USA]] as an affiliate member). Three main sports facilities serve as home venues for Golden Panther athletics. The [[FIU Golden Panthers Football|Golden Panthers football team]] plays at FIU Stadium ("The Cage"), the men and women's basketball and volleyball teams play at the [[U.S. Century Bank Arena]], and the men's baseball team plays at [[University Park Stadium]]. Other athletics venues include the Aquatic Center, Tennis Complex, softball fields, and various other recreational fields.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=11700&KEY=&ATCLID=559523|title=Golden Panther athletic facilities|accessdate=2007-11-10}} U.S Century Bank Arena will undergo an expansion that will include more seating and a more modern entrance. Plans for the expansion are underway. Traditional rivals of the FIU Golden Panthers include [[Florida Atlantic University]] and the [[University of Miami]]. The Golden Panthers football team competes in the annual [[Shula Bowl]], a yearly football game played for the Don Shula Award against in-state rival [[Florida Atlantic University]]. Due to this competition in the Shula Bowl, the rivalry between the two schools has grown, with the rivalry extending into the men's baseball and basketball teams as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=11700&ATCLID=558467&SPID=4780&SPSID=49159|title=2005 Shula Bowl|accessdate=2007-11-10}} The [[FIU Golden Panthers football|Golden Panthers football team]] plays home games at [[FIU Stadium]] nicknamed "The Cage" and are currently coached by [[Mario Cristobal]]. In 2005, the Golden Panthers moved to the Sun Belt Conference, making their transition from Division I-FCS to Division I-FBS complete. In their first season in the conference, the Golden Panthers began by going 5-6.{{cite web|url=https://admin.xosn.com/fls/11700/Stats_Cumulative/Football/2005/teamcume.htm|title=2005 Golden Panthers football season|accessdate=2007-11-10}} FIU's athletics department has produced many professional and Olympic athletes, including current players in [[Major League Baseball]], [[Major League Soccer]], [[National Basketball Association]], [[National Football League]] and the [[Women's National Basketball Association]]. Notable alumni include [[Mike Lowell]] ([[Boston Red Sox]]), [[Raja Bell]] ([[Utah Jazz]]), and [[Carlos Arroyo]] ([[Boston Celtics]]). In 2009, FIU hired [[NBA Hall of Fame]]r [[Isiah Thomas]] as head coach of the men's basketball team.http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/colleges/fiu/story/999115.html In 2010, the Panthers football team finished the season #1 as [[Sun Belt Conference]] champions, and went on to the [[Little Caesars Pizza Bowl]] against [[University of Toledo|Toledo]] on December 26, 2010. The game was won 34-32 in a fourth quarter play that became known as the "Motor City Miracle."http://www.miamiherald.com/2010/12/27/1989647/fiu-rallied-twice-in-the-fourth.html ==Notable alumni== {{Main|List of Florida International University people}} With 160,595 alumni around the world, the [[FIU Golden Panthers]] constitute one of the fastest-growing university alumni groups in the state of Florida. FIU graduates more than 8,000 students a year and confers more than half of all degrees awarded by universities in Miami.{{Dead link|date=August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fiu.edu/docs/about_fiu.htm|title=FIU Alumni data|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-06-16}} Alumni services is run by the FIU Alumni Association, which sponsors numerous alumni events, galas, and ceremonies annually.http://www.fiualumni.com/ In conjunction with the Office of Alumni Relations, the Division of External Affairs publishes a quarterly news and alumni magazine, "FIU Magazine". FIU Magazine is distributed free of charge to all FIU alumni, faculty and donors.http://wordpress.fiu.edu/magazine/about-2/

==FIU in television and entertainment== FIU's campus has been the set for many films, television shows, and music videos. One of the earliest television shows to have filmed at FIU was ''[[Miami Vice]]'' in 1985. In the episode, "The Fix", the [[U.S. Century Bank Arena]] was used as one of the scenes. The TV show ''[[Burn Notice]]'' has also filmed various episodes at FIU, with scenes at the College of Business Buildings and the Diaz-Balart College of Law Building.http://forums.usanetwork.com/index.php?showtopic=406938 In 2007, [[Chris Brown (American singer)|Chris Brown]] filmed the music video for his song "[[Kiss Kiss (Chris Brown song)|Kiss Kiss]]" at FIU, with scenes near the [[Frost Art Museum]] and around the Graham Center. Various [[telenovelas]] for [[Telemundo]] and [[Univision]] have filmed television episodes at FIU as well. In 2007, Univision's ''[[Pecados Ajenos]]'' was filmed in the Graham Center.http://issuu.com/fiumagazine/docs/wintermag08 In 2009, [[TLC (TV channel)|TLC]]'s ''[[What Not to Wear (US)|What Not to Wear]]'' filmed an episode on campus at the Management and Advanced Research Center. In October 2009, former [[CNN]] news anchor Rick Sanchez broadcast his CNN show from the Graham Center at FIU.http://news.fiu.edu/2009/10/cnn%e2%80%99s-rick-sanchez-live-from-the-pit-at-fiu/ The new A&E show [[The Glades (TV series)|The Glades]] shot an episode at University Park, using the [[Frost Art Museum]] as a background and the Health and Life Sciences building as the faÃ§ade for a NASA
